header_1: H5N1 in Wild birds in France.
content_1: Four ducks found dead on August 8 in Diane Capelle in the Moselle  region have tested positive for H5N1. Two “wild species” are reported in the  OIE report, but four "ducks" are reported in news sources. No  information on what species the birds are has been provided. Two swans found  dead at the end of  July in the same area have previously tested positive  for H5N1.
content_2: Local news sources reported on August 11 that H5N1 has been found in farms in three regions to the east of the capital Lome. This is the second time that H5N1 has been detected in Togo. In June,  H5N1 was found in dead chickens at a farm in Sigbehoue. Almost 8,000 birds were killed at the time to control the outbreak. The sale and movement of poultry in Togo’s Maritime region, which includes the capital, Lome, have been banned in an effort to limit the spread of H5N1.
content_3: Bird flu has been detected in a farm in the northern province of Cao Bang. Eighty-nine chickens and ducks have died as of Aug 11 and samples sent to the Animal Health Department have been confirmed to be infected with H5N1. The farm is located about 70 km south of the border with the Chinese province of Guangxi. Cao Bang, which had remained free of bird flu this year, joins Dien Bien and Dong Thap as provinces under bird flu watch, down from a high of 18 provinces.
